docs.lead_paragraph: The pace of legislative activity on tobacco regulation quickened today as several influential Senators staked out their opening bargaining positions. Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said tobacco companies would have to be given considerable protection against lawsuits if their advertising practices were to be restricted.

headline.main: In the Senate, Parties Jockey To Influence Tobacco Deal

docs.abstract: Key senators stake out opening stands on tobacco regulation; Sen Orrin G Hatch says tobacco companies should get considerable protection from suits in exchange for advertising curbs; Sen James M Jeffords offers first draft of bill that would give Food and Drug Administration less authority to regulate tobacco products than agency now claims; Sen Kent Conrad sets news conference on planned bill, backed by most Democratic senators, that would be much tougher on industry than deal industry struck with 40 state attorneys general (M)
docs.snippet: The pace of legislative activity on tobacco regulation quickened today as several influential Senators staked out their opening bargaining positions.    Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said tobacco companies would...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Giuliani administration is laying the groundwork to enforce a 1995 state measure allowing it to expel homeless people from shelters if they violate an array of rules, including failing to participate in drug counseling and job training programs. The measure, promulgated by the State Social Services Department, would for the first time make the right to emergency shelter conditional on whether shelter occupants cooperate with rigid guidelines on conduct. The guidelines would also require individuals and families in homeless shelters to search for permanent housing and to avoid drug use and violence.

headline.main: City Asks an Earlier Verdict On Shelter Eviction Rules

docs.abstract: Giuliani Administration is laying the groundwork to enforce a state Social Services Dept measure that would for the first time allow it to expel homeless people from New York City shelters if they fail to abide by an array of rules; city tried to enact the guidelines when they went into effect in 1995, but a series of court challenges by advocates for the homeless have prevented their being put in place; city seeks early ruling from Justice Helen E Freedman of State Supreme Court (M)
